text: Let's have a go at another scenario now.
You've arrived in a town, perhaps in Tuchat,
and you want to go to the local market.
So, you're going to ask first of all, you're going to say, pardon.
Is there a market here? Literally, pardon.
Is it that there is a market here?
Pardon, est-ce qu'il y a un marché ici?
The person you ask replies, but you don't understand.
Say, I don't understand. Can you repeat, please?
Je ne comprends pas. Pouvez-vous répéter, s'il vous plaît?
Again, you don't understand because he speaks so quickly.
Say, can you speak more slowly, please?
Pouvez-vous parler plus lentement, s'il vous plaît?
He tries again, this time more slowly,
and you actually catch what he's saying.
He says, continue straight on, after the cathedral, turn left.
Continuez tout droit.
Après la cathédrale, tournez à gauche.
Continuez tout droit.
Après la cathédrale, tournez à gauche.
You reply, ah, I understand, thank you.
Ah, je comprends, merci.
You're about to leave, but he continues talking to you.
He says, where are you from?
Literally, he says, you are from where?
Tell him, you're from London.
Say, I'm from London, and you?
Je suis de Londres, et vous?
He tells you that he's from Toulouse.
He says, I'm from Toulouse, I'm Jack.
Je suis de Toulouse, je suis Jacques.
So you give him your own name.
If it was me, I'd say, I am Paul.
Je suis Paul.
You note how smartly dressed he is,
and ask him what it is he does.
Say, what is your profession?
Quelle est votre profession?
He says, I am a civil servant,
I am a functionary, and you?
Je suis fonctionnaire, et vous?
You tell him your profession.
As it's me, we're modelling this on.
Say, I'm a teacher, I'm a professor.
Je suis professeur.
He looks at his watch, and says,
I'm sorry, but I must leave.
Goodbye.
Je regrette, je dois partir.
Au revoir.
Say goodbye.
Au revoir.
Au revoir.
Au revoir.
Au revoir.
Au revoir.
Thank you.
